title: 111_hr3737
content:
The "Small Business Microlending Expansion Act of 2009" allows intermediaries to report borrower information to credit agencies for credit building. It also provides flexibility in credit terms for small businesses. SEC. 3. FLEXIBLE CREDIT TERMS. Amends the Small Business Act to remove "short-term" from certain paragraphs. SEC. 4. INCREASED PROGRAM PARTICIPATION. Section 7(m)(2) of the Small Business Act is amended to require individuals involved in making microloans to have at least 1 year of experience or 1 full-time employee with 3 years of experience in working with startup, newly established, or growing small businesses. The Small Business Act now requires individuals involved in making microloans to have at least 1 year of experience providing intensive marketing, management, and technical assistance to borrowers, or 1 full-time employee with similar experience. SEC. 5 increases the limit on intermediary borrowing to $1,000,000 and $7,000,000, with the possibility of treating it as $10,000,000 if deemed appropriate. SEC. 6 expands borrower education assistance by increasing the percentage to 35%. SEC. 7 introduces the Young Entrepreneurs Program. Section 7(m)(4) of the Small Business Act is amended to include a Young Entrepreneurs Program for providing technical assistance to young entrepreneurs in establishing small businesses and securing financing. The Young Entrepreneurs Program provides technical assistance and financing to individuals aged 25 or younger who have resided in the area served by the intermediary for at least 2 years. If a young entrepreneur establishes a small business after receiving assistance, they must make a good faith effort. The Young Entrepreneurs Program supports individuals aged 25 or younger residing in the intermediary's area by providing technical assistance and financing for establishing or operating a small business. Repayment on loans for these businesses can be deferred for up to 6 months after receiving the final disbursement. SEC. 8 of the Small Business Act is amended to increase the loan size from $7,500 to $10,000. SEC. 9 introduces a reporting requirement. Section 7(m) of the Small Business Act is amended to include a reporting requirement for the microloan program. The Administrator must submit a report to the House and Senate Committees on Small Business detailing the names, locations, funds received, and loans/grants provided to intermediaries for each fiscal year. The report required under Section 7(m) of the Small Business Act must include details on contributions from non-Federal sources, number and amounts of microloans made to different borrower categories, and descriptions of the assistance provided by intermediaries. The report under Section 7(m) of the Small Business Act should detail the assistance provided by intermediaries, including to women, low-income, veteran, disabled, and minority entrepreneurs. It should also cover the number of jobs created, repayment history, and impact of microloans provided. The report should include the repayment history of intermediaries and the number of successful businesses after receiving microloans. SEC. 10. Surplus interest rate subsidy for businesses. The Administrator can provide grants to intermediaries to reduce interest rates for borrowers under this subsection. SEC. 11. Authorization of appropriations. SEC. 11. Authorization of appropriations for fiscal years 2010 and 2011 under the Small Business Act, including $80,000,000 in technical assistance grants, $110,000,000 in direct loans, and $10,000,000 in interest assistance grants. Authorization of appropriations is provided for necessary sums to carry out the programs. SEC. 12. REGULATIONS.

The Administrator must issue regulations within 180 days of the enactment of this Act to implement its provisions. Passed the House of Representatives on November 7, 2009.
